query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Forse semilia miglia di lontano 2 ci ferve l’ora sesta, e questo mondo 3 china già l’ombra quasi al letto piano,
4 quando ’l mezzo del cielo, a noi profondo, 5 comincia a farsi tal, ch’alcuna stella 6 perde il parere infino a questo fondo;
7 e come vien la chiarissima ancella 8 del sol più oltre, così ’l ciel si chiude 9 di vista in vista infino a la più bella.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Perhaps a thousand miles away 2 the sixth hour boils for us, and this world 3 already bends its shadow almost to the flat bed,
4 when the middle of the sky, deep for us, 5 begins to turn such that some stars 6 lose their visibility down to this depth;
7 and as the very bright handmaid 8 of the sun comes further, so the sky closes 9 from sight to sight down to the most beautiful.
**Old English:**
1 Fela sind mile ðæt ðu meaht fysan 2 ðæt ðeos sixte tid sie ðe us swefeð, 3 and ðeos world wendeð hire sceаdu neah ðæm bedde,
4 ðonne ðæs heofones midel, ðe us is deope, 5 onginneð ða to weorðenne swylc, ðæt sume steorran 6 forleosað ðone leoman oð ðisne grund;
7 and swa swa ðeos scireste ðinen 8 ðæs sunnan cymeð furðor, swa ðeos lyft locð 9 ðurh gesihðe to gesihðe oð ða fægerestan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Non altrimenti il trïunfo che lude 11 sempre dintorno al punto che mi vinse, 12 parendo inchiuso da quel ch’elli ’nchiude,
13 a poco a poco al mio veder si stinse: 14 per che tornar con li occhi a Bëatrice 15 nulla vedere e amor mi costrinse.
query.result:
**English:**
10 Not otherwise the triumph that plays 11 always around the point that conquered me, 12 seeming enclosed by that which it encloses,
13 little by little faded from my sight: 14 so that love and the inability to see anything 15 compelled me to turn my eyes back to Beatrice.
**Old English:**
10 Nis naht elles ðæt sigeðe ðe plegað 11 symle ymb ðone stede ðe me oferwann, 12 ðinceð belocen ðurh ðæt ðe hit beluceð,
13 lyt ðurh lyt ðam minum gesyhðe adwæs: 14 forðæm ðe me lufe and ðæt ic naht ne geseah 15 neddon ðæt ic mine eagan to Beatrican gewende.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 Se quanto infino a qui di lei si dice 17 fosse conchiuso tutto in una loda, 18 poca sarebbe a fornir questa vice.
query.result:
**English:**
16 If all that has been said of her up to now 17 were to be summed up in a single praise, 18 it would be too little to do justice to this occasion.
**Old English:**
16 Gif eal ðæt ðe oð ðis gedihte is 17 wære gesamnod on an lofsang, 18 hit wære lyt to ðisse leane.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 La bellezza ch’io vidi si trasmoda 20 non pur di là da noi, ma certo io credo 21 che solo il suo fattor tutta la goda.
query.result:
**English:**
19 The beauty that I saw transcends 20 not only our world, but I believe 21 that only its Maker fully enjoys it.
**Old English:**
19 Þæt fægernes þe ic þær geseah oferfarað 20 na þonne ussa woruld, ac ic wat to soðe 21 þæt his geworht eall hit ana brucað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Da questo passo vinto mi concedo 23 più che già mai da punto di suo tema 24 soprato fosse comico o tragedo:
25 ché, come sole in viso che più trema, 26 così lo rimembrar del dolce riso 27 la mente mia da me medesmo scema.
query.result:
**English:**
22 From this pass overcome I surrender myself 23 more than ever before from any point of its theme 24 whether it was treated as comedy or tragedy:
25 for, like the sun in the face that trembles most, 26 so the remembrance of the sweet smile 27 deprives my mind of myself.
**Old English:**
22 Of ðissum stepe oferwunnen ic me sylle, 23 mare ðonne æfre ær of ænegum his stede 24 ofer ðone wære wyrd geset comice oððe tragedige:
25 forðan, swa ðære sunnan on ðam ansyne ðe mæst bifæð, 26 swa ðæs wynsuman hleahtres gemynd 27 ðone mod minne of me sylfum adwæsceð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Cotal qual io lascio a maggior bando 35 che quel de la mia tuba, che deduce 36 l’ardüa sua matera terminando,
37 con atto e voce di spedito duce 38 ricominciò: «Noi siamo usciti fore 39 del maggior corpo al ciel ch’è pura luce:
40 luce intellettüal, piena d’amore; 41 amor di vero ben, pien di letizia; 42 letizia che trascende ogne dolzore.
query.result:
**English:**
34 Such as I leave to a greater herald 35 than that of my trumpet, which is bringing 36 its arduous subject-matter to a close,
37 with the bearing and voice of a skilled leader 38 he began again: "We have emerged 39 from the greatest body to the heaven that is pure light:
40 intellectual light, full of love; 41 love of the true good, full of joy; 42 joy that transcends every sweetness.
**Old English:**
34 Swylc ic læte to maran byman 35 ðonne ðæs minan трубы, ðe lædeð 36 his heardan efne to ende,
37 mid dædum and stefne ðæs froman lædes 38 eft ongon: "We synt nu ute 39 of ðam mæstan lichaman to ðam heofone ðe is clæne leoht:
40 leoht ðæs modes, ful of lufe; 41 lufu ðæs soðan godes, ful of blisse; 42 blis ðe oferstíhð ælcne swetnysse.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Qui vederai l’una e l’altra milizia 44 di paradiso, e l’una in quelli aspetti 45 che tu vedrai a l’ultima giustizia».
query.result:
**English:**
43 Here you will see the one and the other host 44 of paradise, and the one in those aspects 45 that you will see at the final judgment.
**Old English:**
43 Hēr ðu gesihst ðone ænne and ðone oðerne here 44 ðæs heofonrīces, and ðone ænne on ðæm hiwum 45 ðe ðu gesihst æt ðæm æftemestan dome.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Come sùbito lampo che discetti 47 li spiriti visivi, sì che priva 48 da l’atto l’occhio di più forti obietti,
49 così mi circunfulse luce viva, 50 e lasciommi fasciato di tal velo 51 del suo fulgor, che nulla m’appariva.
query.result:
**English:**
46 Like a sudden flash of lightning that scatters 47 the visible spirits, so that the eye is deprived 48 of stronger objects by the act,
49 so a living light flashed around me, 50 and left me wrapped in a veil of its radiance, 51 so that nothing appeared to me.
**Old English:**
46 Swa swa ðæt scinende leoht ðe ða gesceafta 47 ðara gesewenlicra gasta ðurh ðone sweg 48 ðæs ðunres ðone gesihð ðæs eagan benimeð,
49 swa me ða ðæt beorhte leoht ymbsealde, 50 and me ða mid ðæs sciman scinan gescrýdde, 51 ðæt me ða nanwuht ne æteowde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 «Sempre l’amor che queta questo cielo 53 accoglie in sé con sì fatta salute, 54 per far disposto a sua fiamma il candelo».
query.result:
**English:**
52 Love, which always calms this heaven, 53 welcomes into itself with such salvation, 54 to make the candle ready for its flame.
**Old English:**
52 Lufe, ðe æfre ðisne heofon stilað, 53 onfoð on hine mid swylcre hæle, 54 ðæt he ðone candel gegearwige to his lige.

**English:**
55 No sooner had these brief words come to me 56 than I understood that I was lifted up 57 beyond my own power;
58 and I was kindled with a new vision, 59 such that no light is so pure 60 that my eyes would not have been defended against it;
61 and I saw a light in the form of a river 62 shining with splendor, between two banks 63 painted with marvelous springtime.
**Old English:**
55 Ne wæs ða furðor ðonne ða word cwomon 56 ðas andsware ðurh ðone ðegn ðe ðær wæs, 57 ðæt ic ða ðurh ða mihte ðæs ðe me ðær lædde
58 ðurh ða niwan gesyhðe ðæs leohtes ðæs beorhtan 59 ðurh ða ðe ic ðær geseah ðurh ða gesyhðe ðæs leohtes, 60 ðæt ðær nan leoht nis swa beorht ne swa scene
61 ðæt ða eagan ðæs ðe ðær on locige 62 ðurh ða ðæs leohtes beorhtnesse ðe ðær beorhte scineð 63 ðurh ða ðæs leohtes beorhtnesse ðe ðær beorhte scineð.

Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Anche soggiunse: «Il fiume e li topazi 77 ch’entrano ed escono e ’l rider de l’erbe 78 son di lor vero umbriferi prefazi.
query.result:
**English:**
76 He added: “The river and the topazes 77 that enter and leave and the laughter of the grass 78 are true foreshadowings of them.
**Old English:**
76 He eft cwæð: “Se flōd and ðā tōpazion 77 ðe inngāð and ūt and ðæs gærses hlihan 78 sind hira sōðe foresprecunga.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Non che da sé sian queste cose acerbe; 80 ma è difetto da la parte tua, 81 che non hai viste ancor tanto superbe».
query.result:
**English:**
79 Not that these things are bitter in themselves; 80 but the fault is on your part, 81 that you have not yet seen things so sublime.
**Old English:**
79 Nis ðæt ðæt ða ðing syn bitere of ðæm, 80 ac ðæt ðin agen mod is unþeawlic, 81 ðe ðu ða ðing ne gesawe swylce ða synd.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 Non è fantin che sì sùbito rua 83 col volto verso il latte, se si svegli 84 molto tardato da l’usanza sua,
85 come fec’ io, per far migliori spegli 86 ancor de li occhi, chinandomi a l’onda 87 che si deriva perché vi s’immegli;
88 e sì come di lei bevve la gronda 89 de le palpebre mie, così mi parve 90 di sua lunghezza divenuta tonda.
query.result:
**English:**
82 There is no infant who rushes so quickly 83 with his face toward the milk, when he wakes up, 84 having been delayed from his usual time,
85 as I did, in order to make better mirrors 86 still of my eyes, bending down to the water 87 that flows so that it may improve itself there;
88 and just as the eaves of my eyelids drank from it, 89 so it seemed to me that its length had become round.
**Old English:**
82 Nis nan cild ðe swa hrædlice hreoseð 83 mid ðam andwlitan to ðam meolce, ðonne hit gewæcneð, 84 swiðe lange fram his gewunan,
85 swa ic dyde, for ðan ðe ic wolde betere speglas 86 gyt ðara eagna, hygende to ðære yðe 87 ðe of ðære burnan cymeð ðurh ðæt hit ðær bettre weorðe;
88 and swa swa ðæs wætres ða eafesan druncon 89 minra ehðena, swa ðuhte me ðæt ðæs wætres 90 lengð wære geworden ymbhwyrft.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Poi, come gente stata sotto larve, 92 che pare altro che prima, se si sveste 93 la sembianza non süa in che disparve,
94 così mi si cambiaro in maggior feste 95 li fiori e le faville, sì ch’io vidi 96 ambo le corti del ciel manifeste.
query.result:
**English:**
91 Then, like people who have been under masks, 92 who seem different from before, if they remove 93 the appearance that was not theirs in which they disappeared,
94 so the flowers and the sparks changed for me into greater joy, 95 so that I saw 96 both courts of heaven revealed.
**Old English:**
91 Þa, swa swa folc ðe hæfð under larfum standen, 92 ðe ðinceð oðer ðonne hit ær wæs, gif hit ofscryt 93 ða hiw ðe nis his agen on ðam hit forð gewat,
94 swa wæron me awende to maran blisse 95 ða blostman and ða gnornas, swa ðæt ic geseah 96 begen ða heofonlican heortan geswutelode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 O isplendor di Dio, per cu’ io vidi 98 l’alto trïunfo del regno verace, 99 dammi virtù a dir com’ ïo il vidi!
100 Lume è là sù che visibile face 101 lo creatore a quella creatura 102 che solo in lui vedere ha la sua pace.
query.result:
**English:**
97 O splendor of God, through which I saw 98 the high triumph of the true kingdom, 99 give me the power to tell how I saw it!
100 There is a light up there that makes visible 101 the creator to that creature 102 who has his peace only in seeing him.
**Old English:**
97 Eala, Godes beorhtnes, ðurh ðe ic geseah 98 ðone hean oferwinne ðæs soðan rices, 99 syle me ðone miht ðæt ic secge hu ic ðæt geseah!
100 Leohte is ðær ufan ðe gesýnlicne wyrceð 101 ðone Scyppend ðære gesceafte 102 ðe næfð ðone sibb buton on him ðæt he hine geseo.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 E’ si distende in circular figura, 104 in tanto che la sua circunferenza 105 sarebbe al sol troppo larga cintura.
query.result:
**English:**
103 And it extends in a circular shape, 104 so much so that its circumference 105 would be too wide a belt for the sun.
**Old English:**
103 And hit stent on ðam ymbrenan gegyrlan, 104 swa ðæt his ymbehwyrfte 105 wære ðære sunnan to ðicce gyrdl.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Fassi di raggio tutta sua parvenza 107 reflesso al sommo del mobile primo, 108 che prende quindi vivere e potenza.
query.result:
**English:**
106 Its entire appearance is made of rays 107 reflected from the summit of the first moving heaven, 108 which derives its life and power from there.
**Old English:**
106 Ealle his hiw fægere scinende 107 on ðæs forman weoroldsteorran, 108 ðe ðanon nimð lif and mægen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 E come clivo in acqua di suo imo 110 si specchia, quasi per vedersi addorno, 111 quando è nel verde e ne’ fioretti opimo,
112 sì, soprastando al lume intorno intorno, 113 vidi specchiarsi in più di mille soglie 114 quanto di noi là sù fatto ha ritorno.
query.result:
**English:**
109 And as a cliff in water at its base 110 mirrors itself, as if to see itself adorned, 111 when it is lush and rich with greenery and flowers,
112 so, standing above the light all around, 113 I saw mirrored in more than a thousand tiers 114 all of us who have returned up there.
**Old English:**
109 And swa swa clifu on wætere his neopan 110 gesihð, swylce he hine sylfne geseon wille, 111 þonne he on grene and on blostmum bið fæger,
112 swa ic ðær ufan ofer ðam leohte geseah 113 on ma þonne ðusend staðola 114 eal ðæt folc ðe ðær up cymen wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 E se l’infimo grado in sé raccoglie 116 sì grande lume, quanta è la larghezza 117 di questa rosa ne l’estreme foglie!
118 La vista mia ne l’ampio e ne l’altezza 119 non si smarriva, ma tutto prendeva 120 il quanto e ’l quale di quella allegrezza.
query.result:
**English:**
115 And if the lowest grade gathers in itself 116 such great light, how vast must be the breadth 117 of this rose in its outermost leaves!
118 My sight was not lost in its expanse and height, 119 but took in all the quantity and quality 120 of that joy.
**Old English:**
115 And gif se nyðemesta ðing on him rymð 116 swylce micel leoht, hu mycel is ðara 117 ðara rosan wyde on ðam ytemestan leafum!
118 Min gesihð on ðam widan and on ðam hean 119 ne losade, ac eall ða menigu and ða gecynd 120 ðære blisse heo onfeng.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 Presso e lontano, lì, né pon né leva: 122 ché dove Dio sanza mezzo governa, 123 la legge natural nulla rileva.
query.result:
**English:**
121 Near and far, there, neither bridge nor pier: 122 for where God governs without intermediary, 123 natural law is of no avail.
**Old English:**
121 Neh and feor, þær, ne brycg ne lād: 122 forðæm ðær God sylf butan middel steoreð, 123 þær ne mæg nan gesceaft wiht gewyrcan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Nel giallo de la rosa sempiterna, 125 che si digrada e dilata e redole 126 odor di lode al sol che sempre verna,
127 qual è colui che tace e dicer vole, 128 mi trasse Bëatrice, e disse: «Mira 129 quanto è ’l convento de le bianche stole!
130 Vedi nostra città quant’ ella gira; 131 vedi li nostri scanni sì ripieni, 132 che poca gente più ci si disira.
query.result:
**English:**
124 In the yellow of the sempiternal rose, 125 which fades and dilates and smells 126 of praise to the sun that always blooms,
127 like one who is silent and wants to speak, 128 Beatrice drew me to her and said: "Look 129 how great is the assembly of the white robes!
130 See how far our city extends; 131 see our seats so full, 132 that few more people are desired here.
**Old English:**
124 On ðæm geolo ðære symbleacan rosan, 125 ðe gewunað and wyðeð and stencð 126 lofes stenc ðæm sunnan ðe symble greneð,
127 swylce se ðe swigað and secgan wile, 128 me lædde Beatrice and cwæð: "Loca 129 hu mycel is se hired ðæra hwitena gyrela!
130 Loca ure ceastre hu heo gæð; 131 loca ure setl swa fulle, 132 ðæt lyt manna má þær gewilnod is.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 E ’n quel gran seggio a che tu li occhi tieni 134 per la corona che già v’è sù posta, 135 prima che tu a queste nozze ceni,
136 sederà l’alma, che fia giù agosta, 137 de l’alto Arrigo, ch’a drizzare Italia 138 verrà in prima ch’ella sia disposta.
query.result:
**English:**
133 And in that great seat to which you keep your eyes fixed, 134 because of the crown that is already placed there, 135 before you dine at these nuptials,
136 will sit the soul, which will be exalted below, 137 of the lofty Henry, who will come to set Italy straight 138 before she is ready.
**Old English:**
133 And on ðæm miclan setle ðe ðu ðine eagan healdeð, 134 ðurh ða corona ðe ðær nu is uppan aset, 135 ær ðu to ðisum gifte cymest,
136 ðær sitteð ða sawul, ðe bið her niðan eadig, 137 ðæs hean Henries, ðe to gerihtanne Italie 138 cymeð ær ðan ðe heo gearu sie.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 La cieca cupidigia che v’ammalia 140 simili fatti v’ha al fantolino 141 che muor per fame e caccia via la balia.
query.result:
**English:**
139 The blind greed that bewitches you 140 has made you act like a little child 141 who dies of hunger and pushes away the nurse.
**Old English:**
139 Þæt blinde grædige ðe eow ablendan hafað 140 gelice dæda geworhte eow ðæm lytlan cilde 141 ðe for hungre swyltð and ða fostermoder afyrrað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 E fia prefetto nel foro divino 143 allora tal, che palese e coverto 144 non anderà con lui per un cammino.
query.result:
**English:**
142 And he will be prefect in the divine forum, 143 such then that, openly and secretly, 144 no one will walk with him on the same path.
**Old English:**
142 And he bið ðonne on ðam godcundan gemote 143 swylc ðæt ðonne ægðer ge ðæt digle ge ðæt gesýne 144 ne gæð mid him on ænne weg.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
145 Ma poco poi sarà da Dio sofferto 146 nel santo officio; ch’el sarà detruso 147 là dove Simon mago è per suo merto,
148 e farà quel d’Alagna intrar più giuso».
query.result:
**English:**
145 But little time will God endure him 146 in the holy office; for he will be thrust down 147 there where Simon Magus is for his deserts,
148 and he will make him of Alagna enter lower still.
**Old English:**
145 Ac lyt ðæt God ðone ðolian wille 146 on ðam halgan hade; forðæm he bið aworpen 147 ðær ðær Symon Magus is for his gewyrhtum,
148 and ðone of Alagna ðær læssan inlædeð.
